abstract: <title>Abstract</title> Squamous cervical cancer (SCC) is a major cause of death in women, yet its molecular characteristics are poorly understood. Here, we profiled histopathological and molecular alterations in SCC, and used large language models (LLMs) for interpretation, reasoning, and understanding of multi-modal data. We implemented an immersive-knowledge prompting (iKLP) strategy to trigger LLMs, which interpreted 17.8%-20.3% of omic alterations known to be associated with cancer. Also, the emergence of cross-disciplinary reasoning in LLMs helped for interpreting phenotypic effects of SCC molecular alterations, exemplified by a prognostic biomarker HRG, and targetable kinases, CDK18 and CDK9. With experimental validations, LLM-reasoning showed >2-fold increased confidence for 68.5% of analyzed molecules. Strikingly, LLMs understood the information flow of cell-cell communications, and uncovered a CDK18-mediated immune escaping axis in orchestrating the crosstalk of malignant, immune, and niche cells. We anticipate that LLMs can be used for completely distinguishing between knowns and unknowns in any scientific problems.

SUMMARY
Squamous cervical cancer (SCC) is a major cause of death in women, yet its
molecular characteristics are poorly understood. Here, we profil ed
histopathological and molecular alterations in SCC, and used large language
models (LLMs)for interpretation, reasoning, and understanding of multi-modal
data. We implemented an immersive-knowledge prompting (iKLP) strategy to
trigger LLMs, which interpreted 17.8%-20.3% of omic alterations known to be
associatedwith cancer.Also, the emergenceof cross-disciplinary reasoning in
LLMs helped for interpreting phenotypic effects of SCC molecular alterations,
exemplified by a prognostic biomarker HRG, and targetable kinases, CDK18
and CDK9. With experimental validations, LLM-reasoning showed >2-fold
increased confidence for 68.5% of analyzed molecules. Strikingly, LL Ms
understood the information flow of cell-cell communications, anduncovered a
CDK18-mediated immune escaping axis in orchestrating the crosstalk of
malignant, immune, and niche cells. We anticipate that LLMs can beused for
completely distinguishing between knowns and unknowns in any scientific
problems.
Highlights
 With prompt engineering, LLMs interpreted 17.8%-20.3% of S CC
molecularalterationsknown tobeassociatedwith cancer.
 LLM-emergent cross-disciplinary reasoning facilitated in uncover ing
histopathologicalphenotypic effectsofSCC molecularsignatur es.
 Our following experiments significantly enhanced the confiden ce of
LLM-reasoningwith>2-fold for68.5%of analyzed molecules.
 LLM-aided understanding revealed a CDK18-mediated immune escaping
axis within crosstalkofmalignant, immune,andnichecells.
INTRODUCTION
Human cervical cancer, which is caused by high-risk human papillomavirus
(hr-HPV) infection, is the fourth leading cause of cancer death inwomen,
resulting in 342,000 deaths worldwide in 20201. Squamous cervical cancer
(SCC) that arises in the ectocervix accounts for 75-80% of all cervical cancer
cases2,3. Treatment approaches and outcomes for SCC are highly dependent
on disease stage at diagnosis. Although the prognosis of localized SCC is
relatively favorable, the 5-year survival rate of late-stage, metastatic, or
recurrent SCC is only 16.5%, with the median survival time of 8-13 months4,5.
There is thus an urgent need to improve our understanding of phenotypic and
molecular alterations leading to effective new therapeutic options, especially
foradvancedSCC.
SCC is notable for substantial inter- and intra-tumor heterogeneity in both
phenotypicandmolecularcompositions 6,7,whichcontributetodrugresistance,
metastasis, and tumor relapse8,9. At the molecular level, the Cancer Genome
Atlas (TCGA) research network profiled genomic and transcripto mic
alterations in 178 SCC tumors, and identified numerous molecular signatures,
such as a frequently mutated oncogenePIK3CA 10. On the other hand, the
state-of-the-art (SOTA) deep learning, such as convolutional neural network
(CNN), has been employed to accurately detect or diagnose cervicalcancer
from histopathological images11,12. However, both phenotypic and molecular
characteristics ofSCC were poorly interpreted,reasonedandunderstood.
Recent advances in the next-generation artificial intelligen ce (AI)
technology, namely large language models (LLMs), such as genera tive
pre-trained transformer (GPT) and its variants, may dramatically accelerate
breakthrough innovations in many disciplines13,14. Since 2018, OpenAI have
made several updates from GPT-1 to GPT-3 for artificial intell igence
generatedcontent(AIGC) 15.AlthoughtheparametersofGPT-3reachedupto
175 billion, its answers were still far from comparable to the chain-of-thought
(CoT)fromhumans 16.Withthestrategyofreinforcementlearningfromhuman
feedback (RLHF), instructGPT/GPT-3.5 was fine-tuned to align human
perceptions 17,18, and its sibling model ChatGPT has become a worldwide
popular tool for generating answers in an innovative way19. Although LLMs
have been successfully used for prediction of protein sequences and
structures 20,21, it’s not known whether LLMs can be used for other purposes
beyondprediction.
In this study, we profiled the histopathological and multi-omic landscapes
of SCC from a cohort of 114 Chinese patients. The molecular alterations were
identifiedandthencompletelyinterpretedbyChatGPT,thou ghimplementation
of an immersive-knowledge prompting (iKLP) strategy. Using iKLP, we first
delivered the background knowledge to ChatGPT, which then accurately
distinguished between knowns and unknowns, and interpreted 17.8%-20.3%
of omic alterations known to be functional in cancer. A SOTA pipeline, deep
learning of cancer multi-modal data (deepCMD), was designed for SCC tumor
subtyping and prediction of molecules of interest (MOIs), such as potential
biomarker proteins and therapeutic kinases. Then, cross-disciplina ry
reasoning of LLMs was performed to identify phenotypic effects of MOIs,
whereas our further experimental validations dramatically increased the
confidence of LLM-reasoning with >2-fold for 68.5% of tested MOIs. Together
with a single-cell spatial proteomics (SCSP) profiling, 29 malignant, immune
and niche cell states were recognized. The known information flowof cell-cell
communications was fully understood by ChatGPT, which reasoned ahighly
convincing CDK18-mediated immune escape axis through alteringthe cell
surface markers. Taken together, we not only completely understood known
and unknowns of molecular characteristics in SCC, but also established a
human-AI interactive paradigm that can completely address any scientific
problems. Of note, the emergence of cross-disciplinary reasoning inChatGPT
indicated that the intelligent agent could not only learn and u nderstand
human-like intellectual tasks, but also use its learnt knowledge to form a link
between diverse disciplines, showing a strong property of artificial general
intelligence(AGI).
RESULTS
A framework for complete understanding of SCC by LLMs
In this study, the leading LLM, ChatGPT, was used for interpret ation,
reasoning and providing new biological insights of SCC (Figure1A). From a
Chinese cohort with detailed clinical features (CFs), the histopathological and
molecular profiles in tumors and paired non-tumor adjacent tissues (NATs)
were obtained from histopathological whole slide images (WSIs), proteomics,
phosphoproteomics,exomics, transcriptomics, and SCSP(Figure 1B).Intotal,
we obtained 313 and 332 high-resolution WSIs of hematoxylin and eosin (H &
E) staining of frozen sections of tumors and NATs from 114 SCC patients,
respectively. From 114 patients, we identified 1,394 differentially expressed
proteins (DEPs), 4,598 differentially regulated p-sites (DR Ps), 1,198
differentially phosphorylated proteins (DPPs), 14 frequently mutated genes
(FMGs), and2,424differentiallyexpressedgenes(DEGs)intumo rscompared
toNATs (Figure S1B-F, TableS3,S4).
To trigger the ability of ChatGPT on efficiently answering questions, we
implemented a prompt engineering strategy, iKLP, by querying the biological
functionsofanalteredmolecule,its associationwithcancer,andt hepathways
it involved in (Figure 1C). In each following step, the previousanswers were
included prior to the query as the background knowledge. In this way, we
obtained 19,321 high-quality prompt-generation pairs (PGPs) for all altered
molecules at proteomic, phosphoproteomic and transcriptomic le vels.
ChatGPT completely distinguished knowns and unknowns, and interpreted
17.8%-20.3% of DEPs, DPPs, and DEGs known to be associated with cancer
(Figure 1A), with an accuracy of 52.3%-78.0% by manually checking the
positive responses. Then, the queries were narrowed down to the background
of cervical cancer, and the positive responding rates (P2R) were decreased to
5.7%-8.7% (Figure 1A), indicating that the knowledge is far from saturated for
individual cancertypes.
Mucin-16 (MUC16/CA125) is well known cervical cancer biomarker for
screening or early diagnosis 22,23, and has been identified as the most
significantly upregulated DEP in SCC tumors against NATs, witha logarithmic
fold-change [log2(FC)] of 1.49 (Figure 1E,Adjusted p = 2.63E-07, Table S4A).
Using iKLP, ChatGPT correctly interpreted its functions as a transmembrane
protein to beoverexpressed in cervical cancer24, andpromotecervical cancer
progression potentially through multiple signaling pathways, su ch as
Wnt/β-cateninandSrc kinasesignaling 25,26 (Figure 1D).
From representative tiles of WSIs, we also identified a differential imaging
characteristic (DIC), “StDev_nuclei_AreaShape_MinFeretDia meter”, to be
over-represented in SCC tumors compared to NATs. Then, we adapted iKLP,
byqueryingChatGTPforthemeaningofthisfeature,themeani ngofitshigher
value in H & E images, and the potential relation between this feature and
MUC16 protein expression (Figure 1E). ChatGTP interpreted that this feature
denotes the standard deviation (S.D.) of the minimum Feret diameter of the
nuclei,andahighervalueofthisfeatureindicatesa higherva riationofnuclei’s
size and shape. Then, ChatGTP reasoned that higher MUC16 expression
might be correlated with a higher value of this feature in two ways (Figure 1F,
TableS1). First, tumorregionsof SCC patientswith higherMUC16 expression
mightbemoreheterogenouswithahighervarietyofnucleisizea ndshape 27,
andhaveahighervalueofthisfeaturethanNATs.Alternativ ely,higherMUC16
expression might have greater metabolic tumor burden28, which result in a
higher nuclear density to increase the value of this feature in tumors against
NATs. Based on cross-disciplinary reasoning, ChatGTP reasonably formed a
link between phenotypic effects and molecular alterations. Inthis study, we
obtained 46,939 additional PGPs to reason the phenotypic effects of 72
alteredmoleculesandsingle-cell nucleiprofileson643imagin gcharacteristics
(TableS1).
LLM-aided interpretation of genomic alterations in SCC
Using NATs as control, whole-exome sequencing (WES) analysis identified
19,496non-redundant somatic variants of8,495 codinggenes in SCC tumors,
including 17,312 single nucleotide variants (SNVs), 1,858 inser tions or
deletions(indels),and326multi-nucleotidevariants(MNVs) (TableS3).Intotal,
we identified 14 potential FMGs in SCC tumors, includingPIK3CA (22%),
KMT2D (17%), KMT2C (13%), HUWE1 (10%), FAT1 (10%), EP300 (10%),
NOTCH2 (8%), STK11 (7%), FBXW7 (7%), CASP8 (7%), LRP1B (6%),
ERBB3 (6%),ATRX (6%),and AR (6%)(Figure 2A).
It was reported that APOBEC mutagenesis induced by APOBEC cytidine
deaminases might be the prevalent source of mutations in cervicalcancer
10,29,30. Consistently, we found 55 of 89 (61.8%) tumor exhibiting significant
enrichment for the APOBEC signature (p < 0.05) (Figure 2A), supporting the
mutationalprocessinourSCCcohortwasalsodrivenbyacellularre sponseto
viral infections. By comparison, the mutation frequencies of FMGs identified in
thisstudywere similartoprevious reports 10,31-34, supportingthehigh quality of
ourWESprofiling (Figure2B).
With the help of ChatGPT, the mutation status of 6 potential FMGs,
including PIK3CA, KMT2D, FAT1, FBXW7, CASP8, and LRP1B, were
interpreted known to be associated with SCC, as well as downstream
pathways potentially regulated by these gene mutations (Figure 2X-X). For
example, ChatGPT interpreted that PIK3CA is a component of th e
PI3K/Akt/mTOR signaling pathway that regulates cell growth, su rvival,
differentiation, and motility, and demonstrated thatPIK3CA mutations occurs
in a subset of SCC tumors 31 (Figure 2C). Then, ChatGPT appropriately
reasoned that the PIK3CA mutation might activate the PI3K/Akt/mTOR
signaling pathway to influence cell cycle progression, DNA repair, and
apoptosis, and ultimately promote cell proliferation, survival , and cancer
development 35. Also, the histone-lysine N-methyltransferase KMT2D was
interpreted as a modifier to methylate the lysine 4 of histone H3(H3K4) and
active gene transcription36, and loss-of-function mutations inKMT2D reduce
its methyltransferase activity to alter immune responses37and increase the
susceptibility to HPV infection in cervical cancer38 (Figure 2D). The functional
impacts of the mutations in the remaining 4 FMGs were also well interpreted
andreasonedbyChatGPT (Figure 2E-H).
Classification of SCC patients into clinically interpretable subtypes
The aim of molecular subtyping is the classification of patients into clinically
relevantclusters 10.IncontrasttouseofasingleCF,overallsurvival(OS),here
we applied 16 CFs tightly associated with SCC outcomes (Table S2). Due to
the inefficiency of the unsupervised clustering, we hypothesized that CFs and
molecular or imaging subtypes that are able to predict outcomes should be
consistent with each other, and such a consistency could be iteratively
optimized. Based on this hypothesis, we implemented a subtypingmodule of
deepCMD, which classified SCC tumors into clinically relevant subtypes for
eachtypeofmulti-modal data.
From the results, we found that proteomic subtypes had the strongest
clinical relevance with the CF subtypes ( p = 0.0048), followed by
phosphoproteomic subtypes (p = 0.0149). The 3 proteomic subtypes could be
unambiguously designated as keratin-high (S-I), keratin-low ( S-II), and
inflammation/complement (S-III) subtypes (Figure 3B). S-II I tumors were
associated with advanced FIGO stage (p = 6.07E-07) and larger tumor sizes
(p = 0.0007), both of which are correlated with a worse patient outcome
(Figure 3B).A number of keratin proteins, including KRT5, KRT4and KRT20,
were markedly up-regulated in S-I tumors and down-regulatedin S-II tumors,
supporting the classification of keratin-high and keratin-low subtypes. Notably,
the degrees of keratinization quantified by WSI were highest in S-I and lowest
in S-II (Figure 3C). In S-II, many ribosomal proteins such as RPL10, RPS6,
RPL17, RPS24, RPS4X, RPS15, RPL10L, and RPS4Y2 were up-regulated,
consistent with enhanced protein translation in this subtype (Figure 3B). For
proteomic subtypes, Gene Ontology (GO)-based enrichment analyse s of
subtype-specific DEPs demonstrated that both viral transcriptio n and
translation processes are particularly active in the keratin-high subtypes
(Figure S2D). Tumors in S-III were characterized by higher expression of
members of the complement cascade (C9, C8A, C8G, CP, C5, C3, C8B, C6,
C7,CFB,andMASP-1),andinflammation-relatedproteins (A POH,PGLYRP2,
and LBP). Factors that trigger activation of the complement pathway (IGHG2,
IGHG4, PLG, HRG, F2, PLGLA, PLGLB1, and KNG1) were also upregulated
in S-III (Figure 3B). Moreover, relatively high expression ofmembers of serine
protease inhibitor (SERPIN) proteins might inhibit lysosomal cell death39 in
S-III tumors. We quantified a significantly higher level of immune infiltration in
S-IIIcomparedwith theothertwo subtypes(Figure3C, D).
All subtype-specific DEPs, DPPs and DEGs were completely interpreted
by ChatGPT, as well as potential pathways they involved in (Table S1). For
example, an S-I-specific DEP, desmoglein-3 (DSG3) was interpreted as a cell
adhesion molecule that is upregulated in SCC40, and might promote cancer
growth and spread through modulating multiple signaling pathways such as
PI3K/AKT and MAPK/ERK41,42 (Figure 3E). The 40S ribosomal protein S6
(RPS6), an S-I-specific DEP, was interpreted to be involved in regulating
translationalinitiationandelongation,anditsoverexpressi onincervicalcancer
might be associated with poor prognosis43. The major pathway that RPS6
involved in is the PI3K/Akt/mTOR pathway, in which RPS6 interactswith and
activates mTOR to promote protein synthesis and cell growth20.Alternatively,
RPS6 could also inhibit the tumor suppressive function of TP53 to increased
risk of tumorigenesis 44 (Figure 3E). Taken together, the superiority of
ChatGPT in literature searching and logic presentation libera tes human
scientistsfromtime-consumingandtediousdocumentwork.
Phenotypic effects of potential biomarker proteins in SCC
Next, we sought to identify new tumor- and subtype-specific prot ein
biomarkers. Considering that 1,394 DEPs were identified, it was not possible
to validate each candidate.Acombination of proteins is likely to be a stronger
predictorthananindividualprotein.However,individualp roteinsindispensable
for the predictive value of the combinations might be useful biomarkers for
further clinical application. Thus, we designed a biomarker modul e of
deepCMD to predict tumor-specific or subtype-specific protein combinations,
basedonthehighestareaunderthecurve (AUC)values (Figure 4A ).
For the top 10 tumor-specific combinations, the mean AUC value ofthe
combinations was 0.9654 (Figure 3B). For the 33 proteins in th ese
combinations, we hypothesized that the most reliable marker biomarkers
would be functionally indispensable in SCC. We subsequently determined the
effect of knocking down each gene with small interfering RNAs (siRNAs)
(Table S6) in both HeLa and SiHa cervical cancer cells, with scrambled
siRNAs being used as the negative control. Silencing GINS3, EPCAM,
DHCR24, SERPINB5, ABRACL, GBP1, TAPBP, STAT1, BRI3BP, DTX3L, or
RBM8A induced a > 1/3-fold suppression on the proliferation of HeLa and/or
SiHacells, withatleastonesiRNA(Two-sidedt-test, p <0.05,Figure S2D,E).
Based on immunohistochemistry (IHC), 4 out of 10 proteins, DHCR24, GBP1,
EPCAM, and PSF3, tested with available antibodies were marked ly
up-regulated in tumor cells compared to the normal cervix (Figure 4C, D and
S4F).
Top 10 combinations specific for S-I, S-II, and S-III proteomicsubtypes
contained 21, 31 and 42 individual proteins, respectively (Figure 3B, Figure
S3A-C, Table S5B). We selected the most invasive S-III specific candidate
biomarkers, the histidine-rich glycoprotein (HRG), SEPTIN5, SERPINA4, and
plasminogen (PLG) for IHC validation in 25 SCC tumors. IHC results showed
notable inter-tumor heterogeneity yet with a clear co-expressi on pattern
(Figure 4E, Figure S3G). Based on the high expression of HRG in the 25
tumors (Figure 4E), we tested HRG expression in a second cohort containing
160 SCC patients and confirmed that HRG is associated with advanced FIGO
stage (Figure 4F, G). Moreover, we verified that HRG protein expression
predicted a worse OS in a third independent cohort of 115 SCCs (Figure 4H,
log-rankp<0.05).
We stratified the patients using median as the cutoff for HRG protein
expression, and identified “StDev_nuclei_AreaShape_FormFa ctor” as an
enriched DIC in HRG highly expressed tumors, from representativetiles of
WSIs (Figure S3H,p = 0.0102). Using iKLP mentioned above (Figure 1C),
ChatGPT interpreted that this feature measures the S.D. of “Form Factor”, a
shapedescriptor,ofnuclei,andahighervalueofthisfeaturein dicatesahigher
atypia or variability of nuclear shape, as a hallmark of malignancy. Then,
ChatGPT reasoned that that HRG is involved in multiple biological processes
such as hemostasis, immune response, and cell adhesion, and its higher
expression might be associated with increased cell adhesion or altere d
signaling pathways45, and result in morphological changes in nuclei with a
higher value of this feature. Thus, the phenotypic effect of HRG protein
expressionchanges wasclearly interpretedandreasonedbyChatG PT.
To quantitatively exhibit the importance of our experimental efforts, we
queried ChatGPT on the relations between candidate biomarkerproteins and
SCC, with or without inputting our experimental results. Fromthe results, we
found that 66.6% of the 36 biomarkers with experimental validations could
achieve >2-fold increased confidence of LLM-reasoning (Figure 4J), implying
the key role of human scientists in providing new biological insights, together
with the help of LLMs. The phenotypic efforts of 35 other candidate biomarker
proteinswere alsoreasonedbyChatGPT(TableS1).
Intepretation and reasoning of theareputic kinases
Protein kinases (PKs) are altered and dysfunctional in different tumors
resulting in the dysregulation of signaling pathways and response to
therapeutic agents targeting the PKs. Here, we developed a kinase module of
deepCMD, and predicted 37 potentially important PKs in SCC (Figure 5A,
TableS5C).Then,weperformedknock-downexperimentswithsiRN Asinboth
HeLa and SiHa cervical cancer cells (Table S6). SiRNA targeting 12PKs
induced a > 1/3-fold suppression of proliferation of HeLa and SiHa (Two-sided
t-test, p < 0.05, Figure S4A, B). From the results, 70.2% of the kinases with
experimental validations could achieve >2-fold increased confi dence of
LLM-reasoning.
From the results, siRNAs targeting CDK18 and CDK9 were the most
effective in decreasing proliferation, with CDK9 inhibitorsranking as the top
effective anti-tumor agents in Siha cells (Figure 5B). The re sults were
consistent with previous studies showing CDK9 involving in cervicalcancer
46-48, supporting the reliability of kinase module predictions. More detailed
studiesindicatedthatsiRNAorinhibitorsofCDK9wereeffecti vein vitroinboth
HeLa and SiHa cells (Figure 5C-D, Figure S4C-F). CDK9 inhibitors induced a
G1 phase arrest (Figure S4H). Moreover, using HeLa cell-based xenografts
and 3 cervical cancer patient-derived xenograft (PDX) mouse models, we
found that treatment of mice using CDK9 inhibitor (AZD4573) significantly
suppressedtumorgrowthwithoutapparenttoxicityasindicatedb ybodyweight
(Figure 5E, Figure S5A-C). IHC of tumor slices from these mice confirmed
increased DNA damage (H2AX) and decreased cell proliferation (Ki67) after
treatment(Figure S5D, E).
Ofnote,CDK18hasnotbeenreportedtobeinvolvedinSCCprogr ession.
Unfortunately, selective CDK18 inhibitors are not available.Therefore, we
knocked out CDK18 with CRISPR/Cas9 technology in HeLa cells. Compared
to parental cells, CDK18 depletion markedly reduced the transcription and
proteinlevelsofHPV18oncoproteins(E6andE7)inHeLacells( Figure5F,G).
The E6 oncoprotein has been shown to degrade the tumor suppressor p53
and the E7 oncoprotein can form complexes with the retinoblastoma pRB
tumor suppressor 49. Consistent with these observations, TP53 protein
expression levels were increased and RB protein phosphorylation was
markedly downregulated in all CDK18 knock-out HeLa cell clones (Figure 5F).
Compared to the parental clone, proliferation of CDK18 knock-out clones was
modestly inhibited in vitro (Figure 5H) and tumor growth was completely
suppressed in xenograft mice (Figure 5I), supporting CDK18 as a therapeutic
target in SCC. RNA-seq data further confirmed dysregulated HPV-related
signaling, RB andTP53pathway inCDK18knock-out cells (Figure S5F,G).
Next, we stratified the patients using median kinase activity as the cutoff,
and identified “Granularity_5_Hematoxylin” as an under-represented DIC in
tumors with higher activity of CDK18 and CDK9 (Figure S5Jp = 0.0391).
ChatGPT interpreted this feature measures the heterogeneity in the intensity
of hematoxylin-stained nuclei in WSI tiles, and a higher value ofthis feature
indicates a higher heterogeneity of chromatin structures. For CD K18,
ChatGPT first interpreted its biological functions in transcriptional regulation
during mitotic cell cycle50, and then hypothesized that lower CDK18 activity
might lead to greater heterogeneity in chromatin organization with a higher
value of this feature, because alterations in chromatin structure might disrupt
DNA replication and repair51. However, ChatGPT interpreted the biological
roles of CDK9 in regulating chromatin modifications involved i n active
transcription,suchasH3lysine4trimethylation(H3K4me3)andH3 K36me352.
Thus, ChatGPT hypothesized that lower CDK9 activity might lead t o
decreased levels of H3K4me3 and H3K36me3, resulting in a more closed
chromatin structure, with a lower value of this feature. Taken t ogether,
although the same DIC could be associated with different molecules,the
phenotypic effects might be markedly different, due to the distinct functions of
alteredmolecules.
Again, the contribution of our experiment validations on kinases was
quantitatively evaluated. We queried ChatGPT on the relati ons between
predicted kinases and SCC, with or without inputting our experimental results.
From the results, we found that 70.2% of the 37 candidate kinases with
experimental validations could achieve >2-fold increased confi dence of
LLM-reasoning, further supporting our contributions in filling the gaps of the
existing knowledge. The phenotypic efforts of 35 other predicted kinases were
also reasoned by ChatGPT (Table S1). Also, CDK18 contained higher kinase
activity in S-I subtype, which indicated that CDK18 could be a early stage
markerofSCC (Figure 5K).

3608μmsections.AllsectionsweremarkedbyH &EstainingtoobtainW SIs.
Then, we developed an SCSP module of deepCMD, which reached a high

and other cell images (Figure S6B). By further recognizing different tumor
areas, we manually selected 113 heterogeneous regions with 100× 100 μm2

numbered and then cropped for SCSP profiling (Figure S6A). Seurat, a

As previously described54, we used an entropy-based method to identify
subtype-specificproteins,whichweredifferentiallyup-regul atedinasingle-cell
subtype compared to other subtypes. From the results, the 29 single-cell

representative markers of immune, CAF and malignant cells to demonstrate a

p<<0.01). FromChatGPTinterpretations,we gotaP2Rof 13.1% formarkers
known tobeassociatedwith malignant,immuneorstromal cells (Tab leS1).
The 3D structure of the SCC tumor sample was re-constructed to
visualize the inter-tumor heterogeneity (Figure 6D). We found that CDK18
were highly expressed in 5 single-cell states, including2 malignant cell states,
KRT82/31+ and ALPL+ cells, and 3 TME cell states, PVALB+, FMNL1+, and
AKAP4+ cells. The CD8+ T cells with higher TLE1 expression were also
labeled,andwefoundthattheylocateoutsidetheregionofCDK 18+malignant
cells, but are partially overlapped with CDK18+ niche cells (Figure 6D).
Furthermore,we sought to deconvolutethesingle-cell compositionsof the114
SCC patients. In the population level, the intra-tumor heterogeneity is highly
consistent with the inter-tumor heterogeneity at the single-cell level. For
example,malignantcellsweremarkedlyenrichedintheS-Iprot eomicsubtype,

Foreachsingle-cellstate,theimagesofcellnucleiweresegmented forall

of CDK18 in regulation of transcription and chromatin organization 50, since

An educated signal web of cell-cell communications within SCC
In tumors, malignant cells always participate in cell-cell communication
with immune and stromal cells55, and such a communication is essential for
tumor metastasis and therapy resistance signaling56,57. With observation of
differential immune infiltrating phenotypes in molecular subtypes and the
significantly inhibitory effect of silencing CDK18 in HPV-integrated SCC cell
lines, we integrated 21 single-cell state markers, 11 DEPs, 12 DPPs and 18
ChatGPT-proposedmolecules,including 8 experimentally validatedmolecules,
and modeled an educated signal web of CDK18-centered cell-cell
communications in SCC. From 53 functional associations and 43
protein-protein interactions (PPIs) interpreted by ChatGPT, 35.4% of them
were directed with unambiguous information flow, which helpe d us to
understand the interplay of cell-cell crosstalk.Also, we found that38 of these
associationsandPPIswerenotcoveredbythe8publicPPIdatabase s(Figure
7B). By integrating all descriptions of the signal web, we plotted a word cloud
to present the hotspots, such as “MYC”, “TP53” and “RB1” within thenetwork
(Figure 7D). Together with the interpretation and reasoningof ChatGPT, the
potentially regulatoryroles ofCDK18was completelyunderstood inSCC.
From the single-cell state profile, we observed that two and threecell
states with high CDK18 expression were malignant and niche cells,
respectively. The highest single-cell expression value of CDK18 wasfound in
theKRT82/31+cell state,andtheintracellularsignalingnetwo rk was analyzed
in this cell state. According to previous reports, CDK18 is involved in DNA
repair of the ataxia telangiectasia and Rad3-related (ATR) pathway in gliomas
58. Therefore, CDK18 might be associated with the integration of HPV in
cancer cell genomes to help cancer cells maintaining their own chromosomal
stability 59, and further generating reactive oxygen species (ROS) signals60.
With the help of ChatGPT-interpretation, we reasoned that cancer cells could
releasesuperoxidesignalstotheextracellularmatrixthrough NOX4,causinga
form of programmed cell death (PCD), NETosis, to shield tumor cells from the
killerTcells by neutrophil extracellulartraps (NETs)61,62.
Aftersummarizing theexperimental resultsandthis inference, we queried
ChatGPT about the possible ways in which CDK18 protected malignant cells
from immune cells. By interpretation and reasoning, ChatGPT suggested that
CDK18wouldbemorelikelytoenhancethephosphorylationofret inoblastoma
(RB), a critical tumor suppressor, to regulate the surface antigen programmed
death-ligand 1 (PD-L1)63, which in turn allows tumor cells to evade CD8+ T
cell immune regulation 64 (Figure 7C). With the new inference and
experimental results, the score of ChatGPT-reasoning further in creased,
proving that the confidence in the causal relation was enhanced.
Simultaneously, the potential mechanism of immune escape was also
captured in KRT85+ malignant cells, showing a “don't eat me” signal of CD47
andSIPRAinteractionwith macrophages 65.
Furthermore, we observed the higher expression of a secreted
glycoprotein, thrombospondin-1 (TSP1), in two types of niche cells, FMNL1+
and PVALB+ cells, which also show higher CDK18 expression. ChatGPT also
interpreted that TSP1 could be secreted by endothelial cells and
cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) in the TME, and then bind to CD47 on
innate and adaptive immune cells, like innate-like mucosal associate d
invariantT(MAIT)cell,forimmunesuppression 66,67 (Figure7A).Therefore,we
believed that there existed CDK18-mediated malignant, immune, and niche
cellcrosstalk inSCC.
DISCUSSION
SCC is a prevalent gynecologic malignancy worldwide, and an in- depth
understanding of its molecular characteristics is fundamental toprovide new
solutions for better diagnosis and treatment of the cancer. In recent years, a
number of internationally collaborative projects such as TCGA,International
Cancer Genome Consortium (ICGC), and Clinical Proteomic TumorAnalysis
Consortium (CPTAC) have profiled multi-omics across multiple cancer types,
andhaveidentifiedmanynovelmolecularalterationsprovid ingnewinsightsfor
tumor biology and precision medicine10,68-71. However, such an effort is yet to
be conducted in SCC, and how to appropriately interpret molecular alterations
incanceris still a great challenge.
On the other hand, histopathological WSIs provide a direct, intuitive and
comprehensive means to provide rich phenotypic information on human
diseases at the single-cell level. To date, the SOTA AI technologyhas been
implemented for cancer cell segmentation and classification 72, cancer
diagnosis 73, and prediction of genetic alterations 74-76. How to use
histopathological data to facilitate the interpretation of can cer molecular
alterationsis not known.
Recently, the emergence of the new-generation AI technology, AIGC or
generative AI (GAI), provides a potentially innovative means to accelerate the
scientific discovery 14. The cutting-edge technology of AIGC/GAI is LLMs,
exemplified by the release of ChatGPT by OpenAI15. Although numerous
debates have been raisedtheprosandconsof ChatGPT 14,77-80, its superiority
has been found with extraordinary abilities in text searching, summarizing,
interpreting, andreasoning, comparedto humanscientists.
With the help of ChatGPT interpretation and reasoning, we adopted the
prompt engineering technology, and developed an iKLP strategyto precisely
query ChatGPT, by inputting prior knowledge and/or experimental evidence
before asking questions. Most importantly, the CoTs of human scientists were
deliveredto ChatGPT forperceptionalignment.TheChatGPT- generated texts
were not directly used, but taken as a resource for further human
interpretations. In this way, ChatGPT completely interpreted knowns of 908
molecular alterations in cancer, with a P2R rate of 17.8%-20.3%for different
omic layers. Obviously, biocuration of each molecule manually from the
literature is time-consuming and labor-intensive, and such tedi ous tasks
should outsourced to LLMs, together with following manual curation to ensure
the accuracy. Indeed, we found that non-existent references werefrequently
generated by ChatGTP, together with other factual errors. Theanswers with
errors were excluded before further use. For the accountabilityof AI texts, we
added a timestamp for each prompt-generation pair to ensure the
reproducibility of our study (Table S1). Together with a SOTA deep learning
pipeline,deepCMD,wefurtherenabledSCCtumorsubtypingan dpredictionof
MOIs, including a potential biomarker protein HRG, and two therapeutic
kinases,CDK18andCDK9.
Toexploitthephenotypiceffectsofmolecularalterations,we obtained645
high-resolution WSIs from frozen sections, from tumors with or without paired
NATs of 114 SCC patients (Figure S1A). The ability to performfrozen section
analysis within minutes as compared to days for FFPE analysis could
contribute to rapid implementation of patient management including precision
medicine. Using deepCMD, we analyzed the histopathological data to extract
informative features. Although frozen sectioning might introduce histological
artefacts, our analysis of frozen sections captured multiple tumor pathological
features, which were interpreted and reasoned by ChatGPT to be causally
relatedto correspondingmolecularcharacteristics (Figure 1B-E).
Prior to further experimental verifications, we queried the r elations
between MOIs and SCC, and the confidence of ChatGPT was weak formost
of newly identified candidates. However, when we included the evidence from
experiments, the confidence of ChatGPT-reasoning was dramatica lly
increased with >2-fold for 68.5% of tested MOIs, indicating the importance of
human scientists’ efforts in uncovering the new biological findings. Finally, we
re-constructed an educated signal web centered on CDK18 to understand the
cell-cell communications in SCC. In the signal web, there were 71 ×70 / 2 =
2485 potentially pairwise associations among the 71 molecules. Itwas not
possibleforahumanscientistto check all associations,which were easily and
rapidly accomplished by ChatGPT. In total, 96 known functional associations
or PPIs were interpreted by ChatGPT, which pinpointed the dir ected
information flow for 35.4% of the associations. With the help of ChatGPT, this
signal web was completely understood, and three potential cell-cell interaction
patterns have been reasoned, including suppressing, blocking or deceiving of
protective immunecellsby malignantorTMEcells mediatedbyCD K18.
Taken together, our study not only profiled molecular alterations with but
alsocompletelydistinguishedknownsandunknowstofurtherunder standSCC.
Besides interpretation of genomic mutations, molecular subtypes, biomarkers,
actionablekinasesandsingle-cell states,LLMshelpedustoreasono utcausal
relationsforthesemolecularalterationsandcorrespondingph enotypiceffects,
as well as an educated signal web for elucidating the cell-cell communication
in SCC. Thus, with educated queries from human scientists, LLMs would
efficiently provide highly useful information for interpreting and reasoning the
big biomedical data, toward a complete understanding of knowns a nd
unknowns for any given scientific problems. We anticipate that such an
immersive-knowledge strategy might enable a fast, accurate, and low-cost
means for feasible application in any scientific research. In addition, the
emergence of cross-disciplinary reasoning that forms links betweendifferent
disciplines based on the learnt knowledge strongly implied the coming of a
neweraof AGI.
Limitations of Study
There are several limitations in our study. First, only 645 high-resolution WSIs
were obtained for extracting and analyzing histopathological imaging features
with a limited ethnic diversity of 114 Chinese SCC patients. We believe that
the results could be refined and further validated through theassessment of
additional WSIs particularly encompassing a diverse ethnic backgr ound.
Second, our experimental approaches were performed on a limited number of
patient samples and SCC models. Analysis of additional patient samples and
preclinical SCC models could provide the power to identify additional novel
findings and to provide further validation and generalization of the findings.
Third, there were many types of clinical imaging data, such as computed
tomography(CT)imaging,magneticresonanceimaging(MRI), a ndultrasound
imaging that were not included in these studies. Including these imaging data
types could provide an improved ability to identify relevant imaging
characteristics of SCC. Fourth, due to budget limitations, we only conducted
SCSP profiling of 113 samples. Additional SCSP data is expectedto provide
deeper insights into the single-cell heterogeneity of SCC and to aid in the
identification of additional therapeutic targets and potential biomarkers. Of
note, the minimum resolution of the SCSP profiling is currently tens of cells,
and we hope to improve this technology to reach a single-cell resolution.
Finally, more usages of LLMs should be tested to providing a bett er
understandingofthe pathophysiology andtherapeuticmanage ment ofSCC.

EXPERIMENTAL MODEL AND SUBJECT DETAILS
Ethics and Collection of Clinical Samples
Paired tumors and NATs of 114 newly diagnosed, untreated SCC patients
were acquired from the biobank of cervical cancer from patients wh o
underwent primary surgery from May 2015 to December 2019. Patients with
prior history of other malignancies within 12 months, any systemi c
chemotherapy, endocrine or biological therapy as well as prior radiation
therapy to the abdomen or pelvis for any cancer type were excluded from the
study. Tissue specimens were collected within 30 min after surgery and
quickly frozen in liquid nitrogen. All of the patients were staged according to
the 2009 FIGO staging system. The histopathological features, including
histological type, pathologic grade, depth of cervix stromal in vasion,
lymphnode metastasis, and lymphovascular space invasion (LVSI), were
histopathologically confirmed with FFPE slide post-surgery by professional
pathologist. This study has been approved by the Ethics Committee of Tongji
Hospital ofHuazhongUniversity of Science and Technology, andeachpatient
hassigneda writteninformedconsent.
Collection of Clinical Data
In addition to the basic information of the patients, the corresp onding
examination data of the patients in the hospital were also collected, including
imaging examination, HPV detection, tumor biomarkers examin ation
(AFP, squamous cell carcinoma antigens such as SCCAg, CA125, and CEA,
etc.), blood routine, urine routine, biochemistry, coagulation, blood sugar and
other examinations. At the same time, the corresponding records of the
patients' treatment during the hospital, such as radiotherapy a nd
chemotherapy, were also recorded. Detailed clinicopathologic features were
summarizedinTableS2.
Cell culture
HeLa and SiHa, two human cervical cancer cell lines, were purchased from
American Type Culture Collection (ATCC). All cell lines were fingerprinted by
short tandem repeats and confirmed to be free of mycoplasma contamination.
Cells were cultured in DMEM media plus 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and
grown ina 37°C incubatorwith 5%CO2.
Animals Models
6-week-old female BALB/C nude mice were purchased from GemPharmatech
Co., Ltd Company (Nanjing, China) and acclimated for 1 week before the
experiment under specific-pathogen-free conditions. All mice received human
care and the whole procedure was performed in accordance with the
guidelines of the Committee on the Ethics of Animal Experiments of Tongji
HospitalofHuazhongUniversity of ScienceandTechnology,Wuhan , China.
METHOD DETAILS
Data processing of histopathological WSIs
Labeling and interpretation of WSIs
Toprepare a benchmark data set fortraining models of single-cell recognition,
wefirstcroppedallWSIsintocontinuouslynon-overlappedtile swith128×128
pixels. To accurately distinguish the cell profiles, we randomly marked the
borders of 18,789 cells by hand, in which the areas of inside single cells were
labeledin whiteandotherregions outsidecells were maskedinbl ack.
For single-cell classification, we randomly labeled 15,032 cancer cells,
11,375 immune cells and 113,308 other cells by hand. Each cell wascropped
andputintothecenterofasmallertilewith64×64pixels.Forar earecognition,
we randomly chose 26 WSIs to manually label the 4 typical areas, including
parenchyma, stroma, keratinization and vessel, and the labeled areas were
1.87×109, 1.88×10 9, 1.74×10 7, and 3.12×10 7 pixels, respectively. For
preparation of different benchmark data sets, WSIs in TIFF format were
manually labeled and interpreted by two pathologists (T.S., a senior
gynecological pathologist with >20 years’ experience; F.L., a gynecological
pathologistwith >10years’experiencein interpretingWSIs).
Tile-based QC
To evaluate whether tiles from tumors or NATs could accurately distinguished,
we cropped WSIs of tumors or NATs into continuously larger and
non-overlappedtileswith256×256pixels formorerapidtra ining.Alltilesfrom
tumors or NATs were taken as input to train a CNN model, and the
performance of classification of tumor- or NAT-derived tiles was evaluated by
the10-foldcross-validationforQC.Tumortiles were usedforWSI -Subtyping.
Representative tiles
To preserving the maximum amount of information, we selected thetile with
the most colored pixels in WSIs of each patient. In order to extract features, fit
thesubtypesofpatients,thescoreofkeratinsfromarearecogniti onmodeland
the infiltration score from cell infiltration estimation were applied. We selected
tileswith highestkeratinscore andwith highestcell infiltrationvalue.
Extraction of quantitative features from images.
A segmentation and feature extraction pipeline was built usingCellProfiler
v4.2.1. The pipelinefirst unmixed H&E stains using the ‘UnmixColors’ module,
thustheHematoxylinstainlayerwasextractedforfurtheranal ysis.Afterallthe
cellnucleiintheimagesweresegmentedwith‘IdentifyPrimary Objects’module,
644 element features were designed with modules including ‘Me asure
Granularity’, ‘Measure Image Area Occupied’, ‘Measure Image Intensity’,
‘Measure Object Intensity’, ‘Measure Object Intensity Distribution’, ‘Measure
Object Size Shape’ and ‘Measure Texture’. Features of each cell w ere
extracted and aggregated across the tile by mean, median, s.d. and deciles
(10-quantiles) of the values. The quantitative features covered the size,
shapes, pixel intensity distributions, textures of the objects, aswell as the
relation between neighbouring objects. The same image-processing pipeline
wasutilized onrepresentative tilesto interpretmolecularsign atures.
The iKLP strategy
For prompt engineering, there were three modules in iKLP. Each of these
modules contained three steps to query the valuable informati on from
ChatGPT. The three modules were used in molecular interpretat ion,
cross-disciplinary reasoning and new insights finding, respectivel y. The
detailedmodelsandsteps were shown below:
i) Theinterpretationmodule.
The first step queried the basic informationfor analtered molecule. Based
on the answer of the first question, the second step appended the contextual
information, such as cancer or cervical cancer. The third step queried a
well-established or potential pathway the altered molecule involved in to
regulatecancerorcervical cancer.
Prompt 1 (by human researchers):
“Can you tell me the function of the protein "MUC16" (Mucin-16) of
human?"
Response 1 (by ChatGPT):

NATs as revealed from the SDS-PAGE image without obvious pro tein
degradation and aberrant pattern. Finally, 114 high-quality paired samples
were selected for the multi-omic analysis. All tumors and NATs were then

WES data analysis
Library construction was performed with 1µg DNA per sample using Agilent
SureSelect Human All Exon V6 kit (Agilent Technologies, CA, USA) following
the manufacturer’s recommendations. Briefly, DNA was fragmen ted to
180-280bpbyhydrodynamicshearingsystem(Covaris,Massachusetts,U SA)

enrichment PCR using Kapa HyperPrep reagents. The resulting libraries were
hybridized with liquid phase with biotin labeled probe, then processed using
magnetic beads with streptomycin to capture the exons of genes. Captured
libraries were enriched in a PCR reaction to add index tags to prepare for
sequencing. Products were purified using AMPure XP system (Beckman
Coulter, Beverly, USA) and quantified using the Agilent highsensitivity DNA
assay on the Agilent Bioanalyzer 2100 system. The clustering of the
index-coded samples was performed according to the manufacturer ’s
instructions. After cluster generation, the DNA libraries were sequenced on
IlluminaNovaSeqplatformand150bppaired-endreadswere g enerated.

The clean reads of WES were obtained after the exclusion of low-quality
paired reads, and mapped to the UCSC hg38 reference sequence84. The
maximalexactmatches(mem)programoftheBurrows-WheelerAli gner(BWA,
version 0.7.17, http://bio-bwa.sourceforge.net/

and addition of read groups. After the convert format from sam files with

http://broadinstitute.github.io/picard/

scores. The variants were called from tumors and paired NATs withMuTect2
program of GATK. The gene- and filter- based annotation of Funcotator
program of GATK were performed for variant annotation. Mutations in RNA
genes, the coding exons of transcripts with a complete open reading frame,

region,and5'flankingregionwereremoved.Forobtainingth ereliablesomatic

≤1.

learning framework for image recognition94. In our CNN framework, there
wereaninputlayer,4setsofdualconvolutionallayersandone poolinglayer(2
× 2), a dense layer and an output layer. In the convolutional layers, the ReLU
function was adopted to activate the outcome of a neuron. The lasthidden
layer is a fully connected (dense) layer for generating prediction outcomes. In
the output layer of CNN models, softmax was utilized as activation function,
and three scores ranged from 0~1 were calculated to represent the probability
ofacell tobea cancer,immune orothercell,respectively.

Conventional clustering strategy
First, the log2-transformed FC values of all DEPs were used for clustering
using the ConsensusClusterPlus (version 1.54.0,
http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/ConsensusClusterPlus.ht
ml) package of R97. The basic parameters were set as follows:k-means
clustering with up to 6 clusters (maxK = 6), 1,000-time repetitions (reps =
1,000), resampling 80% of samples (pItem = 0.8) and resampling 80% of
proteins (pFeature = 0.8). The number of clustering was determined by the
average pairwise consensus matrix within consensus clusters, and the delta
plotoftherelativechangeintheareaunderthecumulativedist ributionfunction
(CDF)curve.Becausetheconsensusmatrixwith k =3or k =4deemedtobea
cleanest separation among clusters, and the delta plot showed that there was
little increase in area fork = 3 compared tok = 4. Thus, the SCC proteomic
datawere clusteredinto3subgroups.
Using the same parameters, the log2-transformed FC values of all DPPs
and DEGs were used for clustering at each omic layer using the
ConsensusClusterPlus.

Model training and parameter optimization
Formodeltraining,the10-foldcross-validationwas usedtoprev entoverfitting.
We randomly generated a training dataset and a testing dataset with a size
ratio of approximately 9:1. We further randomly split the training dataset into
ten parts, of which nine were used for model training. Then, we used the
remaining part to calculate the average Ac value, and the process of
parameter optimization was stopped when the Ac value was no longer
increased. The randomization and parameter optimization on the training
datasetwasperformedtentimes,andthemodelwiththehighest Ac valuewas
retained.Using the determinedparameters, the final model was trained onthe
full training dataset. The testing dataset was not used for training, and was
only used to countTP, TN, FP and FN values and calculate the performance
measurements.
A lab computer with an Intel(R) CoreTM i7-10700K@ 3.80 GHz central
processing unit (CPU), 64 GB of RAM and a NVIDIAGeForce GTX 2060 core
was used for model training. The Keras version 2.2.4
(http://github.com/fchollet/keras
), a highly useful neural networksAPI that was
written in Python and developed based on the TensorFlow 1.13.1
(https://github.com/tensorflow
), was adoptedforparallelcomputing. U-Net and
CNN models were trained by minimizing cross entropy loss between final
predictions and ground truth labels. During training, the Adam optimizer in

Functional experiments of protein regulators
Cell counting after interfered with RNA interference (RNAi) or inhibitors
The siRNAs were synthesized by Millipore Sigma Company (Burlington, MA,
USA, Table S6). Scramble siRNA was used as a negative control. Cells were
transfected with siRNAs using Lipofectamine TM 3000 (ThermoFisher
L3000015, Waltham, MA, USA) at 50 nM final concentration. CCK-8 assays
(Dojindo Laboratories, Japan) were used to detected cell counts 72h after
transfection. Three independent replicates were performed fo r each
experiment.
To test the anti-tumor effects of PK inhibitors, 3000 HeLa or SiHa cells
were plated in 96-well plates, and then treated with inhibitors as indicated for
72 h, thereafter CCK-8 assays (Dojindo Laboratories, Japan) were used to
detected cell counts. At least three independent replicates wereperformed for
eachexperiment.
Cell proliferation assay
For observing the effect of RNAi on cell proliferation,1500 HeLaor SiHa cells
24 hours after transfection with indicated siRNA were plated in 96-well plates
for, and then cell proliferation were detected by CCK-8 solution (Dojindo
Laboratories,Japan)atdifferenttimepointsas indicated.
Colony formation assay
HeLa or SiHa cells were seeded into 12-well plates (1500 per well) and
allowed to adhere about 12 hours. Cells were cultured for another 9 days with
different drugs with concentrations as indicated. Cells were then fixed with 4%
paraformaldehyde, stained with 0.5% crystal violet, and photographed using a
digital scannerafterdrying.

Feng Zhang. SgRNA sequences for CDK18 interference are designedwith

. The

Western blot analysis
Cells were treated as indicated and total protein was extracted from the
collected cells with RIPA lysis buffer, and the protein concentration was
determined with Coomassie blue. Every sample was added with 20%loading
buffer and boiled for 15 minutes, then 20ug of total protein was added to each
well by SDS–PAGE gels. After transferring with PVDF membrane,it was
blockedwith 5% nonfat dry milk inTBSTfor 1h atroom temperature,and then
incubated with primary antibody (antibody information wereprovided in key
resources table) at 4 °C overnight. The secondary antibodies wereincubated
for 2h at room temperature. The signal of western blot was collected using
enhancedchemiluminescence(Bio-Rad).
qRT-PCR assay
According to the steps of the instructions, the total RNAwas extracted using a
total RNA isolation kit (Vazyme Cat. RC112-01). Next, total RNA(1 μg) was

Cell Cycle assay by flow cytometry
To measure the cell cycle, cells were treated with different concentrations of
inhibitors for 48 hours, then harvested for flow analysis. Aftercollecting cells,
the cells were fixed in 75% alcohol at 4 degrees overnight. Next, cells were
washed with PBS and stained with 20 mg/ml propidium iodide (PI)which
contained 100 mg/ ml RNase A. Finally, the samples were detected by flow
cytometry (Beckman Coulter), and at least 10,000 cells were detected in each
sample.FlowJo-V10software was usedtoanalyze data.

80+ddH2O. The mice were treated as follows: 1) Vehicle; 2) AZD4573 20
mg/Kg, oral gavage, BID, 2h apart, 2 days on 5 days off; 3) BI6727 10 mg/Kg,
oral gavage, QD, 4 days on 3 days off. The tumor volume was calculated as
follows: V = (L×W2)/2 (L: length; W: width). All mice were sacrificed at the
endpoint of drug administration and tumors were harvested for subsequent
experiments.
In addition, 5×106 parental HeLa cells and the CDK18 KO cell clones
(sg#b2 or sg#e1) were transplanted into the right and left flanksat the same
micerespectively.Mice were monitoredandsacrificedas mentioned above.
PDX experiments
All PDX mouse models of cervical squamous cell cancer were established
previously in our lab.All established PDX models have been approved by the
Ethics Committee of Tongji Hospital of HUST, and each patient has signed a
writteninformedconsent.
Forin vivoexperiments,freshtumortissueofPDXswereminced(0.1–0.2
cm3), and then subcutaneously implanted on the right side of 6-week-old
female BALB/C nude mice. When the volume of xenograft tumors reached
approximately100mm3,micewere randomly grouped(5 or6mice p ergroup)
andtreated asfollows:1) Vehicle; 2)AZD457320 mg/Kg, oral gavage, BID, 2h
apart,2dayson5daysoff;3)BI672710mg/Kg,oralgavage,QD, 4days on3
days off. The drugs (AZD4573: Selleck CAS No. 2057509-72-3, BI6727:
Selleck CAS No. 755038-65-4) were all dissolved in 2% DMSO+30%
PEG300+5% Tween 80+ddH2O. Mice were monitored and sacrificed as
mentionedabove.
IHC
All tumor tissues were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde overnight and
paraffin-embedded. IHC was performed on 4μm-thick sections. Embedded
IHC sections were deparaffinized in xylene and hydrated firstly.All slides
were boiled in antigen retrieval solution (citrate buffer, 10mM, and pH 6.0) for
15 minutes and blocked in 3% hydrogen peroxide for 15 min at 37°C.Slides
were rinsed in PBS 3 times and blocked with 5% goat serum albumin for 60
minatroomtemperature.Next,allslideswereincubatedwithp rimaryantibody
(antibody information were provide in the key resources table)overnight at
4 °C. Incubating the biotinylated secondary antibody and horsera dish
peroxidase according to the instructions (ZSGB-BIO, Rabbit SP kit, SP-9001;
Mouse SP kit, SP-9002). Subsequently, slides were incubated with DAB
(ZSGB-BIO, DAB Chromogenic kit, ZLI-9018) and then stained wi th
hematoxylin.Aftercoverslipping,slideswerescannedunderamicr oscopeand
photographed. Tumor cell staining were semi-quantified with five-category
grading system: 0, no staining; 1, 1-25% staining; 2, 26-50% staining; 3,
51-75% staining; and 4, >75% staining, and staining intensity wa s
semi-quantified with five-category grading system: 0, no staining; 1, weak
staining; 2, moderate staining; 3, moderate-strong; and 4, strong staining.The
final IHC score was obtained by the formula：Tumor cell staining × staining
intensity for each protein. Every core was assessed individually and the mean
of three readings was calculated for every case. The IHC score was
determined separately by two independent experts simultaneously under the
same conditions. In rare cases, discordant scores were reevaluated and
scoredonthebasis ofconsensus opinion.
RNA-seq and GSEA analysis
The HeLa cells and HeLa CDK18 Knockout sg#b2 cells were collected and
extracted the total RNA using an RNA extraction kit (Vazyme Cat. RC112-01).
After determining of RNA concentration and integrity, total RNA was used to
generate poly(A)+ RNA for construction of an RNA-seq library by Annoroad
Gene Technology Co., Ltd. RNA-seq was performed on the MGISEQ-2000
platform. All samples have 3 independent biological replicates. The pathway
enrichment analysis was explored with GSEA analysis with the clusterProfiler
package.
Survival analysis
For HRG or PLK1, we stratified SCC patients into two groups as high and low
protein expression, based on the TMA results. To evaluate the prognostic
powerofeachprotein,thetwo-sidedlog-ranktestisperformed fortheOSdata
(p < 0.05), and the Kaplan-Meier survival curve was illustrated by Survival
Analysis package (survival 3.2-7,
https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/survival/index.html
).
Quantification and statistical analysis
The methods of quantification and statistical analysis for single-omic data
analysis,multi-omicdataanalysis,clinicaldataanalysisandexper imentaldata
analysis were carefully described in corresponding Method Details
subsections. Standard two-sided statistical tests used in this study included
but not limited to log-rank test, Fisher’s exact test, Spearman’s correlation,
hypergeometric test, Student’s t test, and chi-square test. For categorical
variables vs. categorical variables, the chi-square test was used. For
categorical variables vs. continuous variables, the Kruskal-Wallis test was
used to test if any of the differences between the subgroups were statistically
significant. For continuous variables vs. continuous variables, Spearman
correlation was used. To account for multiple-testing, the adjusted p values
were calculated using the BH correction. For experimental validations, each
assay was independently repeated for ≥ 3 times, and results were present as
mean ± standard rrror of the mean (SEM). The statistical significance of
differenceswasestimated bytwo-sidedStudent’s t test.
